item.title: EA Sports College Football Is $25 At Best Buy
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/ea-sports-college-football-is-25-at-best-buy/1100-6528793/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

PS5 and Xbox Series X owners can snag a copy of EA Sports College Football 25 at Best Buy right now for just $25 (down from $70). Best Buy does not say how long this limited-time discount will last, so it's worth picking up the game while it's still available.

EA Sports College Football 25 marks the return of EA's college football video game series, which hadn't seen a new entry since EA Sports College Football FC 14 in 2013. Given the length in time between releases, it's fair to say fans had high expectations. Luckily, it launched to positive reviews, with GameSpot's Andrew MacMahon scoring the game an 8/10, saying, "EA Sports College Football 25 perfectly encapsulates what attending a college football game is like. Vibrant and viciously loud crowds, hundreds of university-specific walkouts and traditions, and uniquely designed stadiums make each school's ambiance give off its own air of distinct excitement."

This Best Buy discount is the perfect opportunity to check the game and its many online and offline modes out for yourself.

If you're looking for more physical game deals, you can grab the Marvel vs. Capcom Fighting Collection for just $35 on Switch or $40 on PS4, which are nice discounts from their usual $50 price tags. Select PS5 exclusives are also on sale at Walmart and Amazon.

item.title: Mai Shiranui Unleashes Fire In Her Street Fighter 6 Gameplay Trailer
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/mai-shiranui-unleashes-fire-in-her-street-fighter-6-gameplay-trailer/1100-6528792/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Street Fighter 6 marks the first time that Fatal Fury characters like Mai Shiranui have appeared in Capcom's mainline series, but not the first encounter between the two fighting game franchises. Capcom vs. SNK: Millennium Fight 2000 brought them together 25 years ago, but their last crossover was in 2003's SNK vs. Capcom: SVC Chaos. So it's high time for a rematch between Fatal Fury's icon and her counterpart, Chun Li, in Street Fighter 6's first gameplay trailer for Mai.

Many of Mai's classic moves remain in her arsenal, but she also seems to have greater control of her fire-infused moves, as well. Mai is so powerful here that she trounces both Chun Li and Ryu when she unleashes her full power. Mai also has a new outfit in addition to her famous red costume.

As glimpsed in Mai's teaser trailer last month, her Fatal Fury stage looks like it got an update for her appearance in this game. Although Smash Bros. creator Masahiro Sakurai felt that it was inappropriate to add Mai to Nintendo's Super Smash Bros. Ultimate, she previously made a guest appearance in Namco's Dead or Alive 6.

Capcom hasn't revealed when Mai will be added to Street Fighter 6 beyond a vague "Winter 2025" release window. Her fellow Fatal Fury fighter, Terry Bogard, was added to Street Fighter 6 last year. Both Terry and Mai will also be among the returning fighters in Fatal Fury: City Of The Wolves when it hits Xbox Series X|S, PlayStation 5, and PC on April 25, 2025.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Dynasty Warriors: Origins - Guides Hub
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/dynasty-warriors-origins-guides-hub/1100-6528754/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Dynasty Warriors: Origins features the Wanderer, a lone soul who has no memory of his past. Still, his journey leads him to meet a memorable cast of characters, from cunning officials and wise strategists to sworn brothers and mighty generals. This is the era of the Three Kingdoms of China, one where the land is constantly ravaged by internecine conflict and where regional lords are hungry for power. This is the next entry in Koei Tecmo's hack-and-slash video game franchise, where bold changes and bigger battles await. Here's our Dynasty Warriors: Origins guides hub to help you on your adventure.

Table of Contents [hide]

  • Dynasty Warriors: Origins guides hub
    • General guides
    • Officers and campaign progression
    • Weapons and special items

Dynasty Warriors: Origins guides hub

Our Dynasty Warriors: Origins guides hub is divided into multiple categories. First, we look at a few general mechanics, followed by tips regarding officers and progression. We then discuss weapons and items that you can obtain during your playthrough.

General guides

Our general guides discuss a few tidbits that are important if you're just starting out. We've got several tips that are perfect for newcomers to the series, as well as veterans who want to learn about the important changes. Perhaps you also want to know how many hours you need to spare just to clear the campaign.

How long to beat the campaign

Beginner's guide: 16 things you need to know before you play

Officers and campaign progression

Gone are the days when Dynasty Warriors had over 90 characters. Now, the only playable fighter is the Wanderer. Still, you can meet various officer companions who can aid you during battles. Moreover, there are key decisions to make and side quests to complete during the campaign. And, of course, you're going to have to pursue Lu Bu whether you like it or not.

How to unlock all officers companions

How to beat Lu Bu

Chapter 3 major decision: Join Cao Cao, Liu Bei, or Sun Jian

Side quest: Search for Memories/Shards of the Past

Weapons and special items

While progressing through the game, you'll acquire all sorts of goodies. There are multiple weapon types with their own unique skills, and you can even upgrade them further. Likewise, the Old Coins you amass can be exchanged for additional rewards.

How to unlock all weapon types

How to reforge and upgrade weapons

Old Coins locations and rewards

We'll continue adding more articles to our Dynasty Warriors: Origins guides hub, so stay tuned.

Jason Rodriguez on Google+

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Switch Copies Of Marvel Vs. Capcom Fighting Collection Are Just $35
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/switch-copies-of-marvel-vs-capcom-fighting-collection-are-just-35/1100-6528791/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The Nintendo Switch version of Marvel vs. Capcom Fighting Collection: Arcade Classics is down to just $35 at Amazon (was $50). This is a great chance to pick up an excellent collection of classic Capcom titles on a single cartridge.

If you're not on Switch, or would prefer playing on a different platform, you can grab the PlayStation version for $40. The Steam version is also available for just $41 at Fanatical. An Xbox version is planned to launch later this year, but is not yet available.

The Marvel vs. Capcom: Fighting Collection includes seven classic Capcom fighting games and brawlers:

  • Marvel vs. Capcom
  • Marvel vs. Capcom 2
  • Marvel Super Heroes
  • Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter
  • The Punisher
  • X-Men: Children of the Atom
  • X-Men vs. Street Fighter

For many of these games, this collection is the first time they've been officially available in many years. Each game includes all the content of its original arcade version and is enhanced with a crisper graphical presentation and online matchmaking with roll-back net code. That makes this collection one of the best--and in some cases only--ways to play them on modern consoles.

Marvel vs Capcom Fighting Collection: Arcade Classics deals

  • Switch -- $35 ($50)
  • PS4 -- $40 ($50)
  • PC (via Fanatical) -- $41 ($50)

Capcom's next big fighting collection, Capcom Fighting Collection 2, is also coming soon. It's marquee titles include Capcom's other historic cross-over series, Capcom vs SNK and Capcom vs SNK 2. The new collection launches on Switch, PS4, Xbox One, and PC sometime in 2025. Preorder copies are available for the physical Switch and PS4 versions, which include a limited-edition Capcom vs SNK comic.

Speaking of SNK fighting games, the company is returning with its next big fighting game, Fatal Fury: City of the Wolves, launching for PS5, Xbox Series X|S, and PC on April 24. Many of the characters in the roster will also appear in the games included in the upcoming Capcom Fighting Collection 2. Digital preorders for the game are available now, with physical preorders planned to launch later.

Disclosure: GameSpot and Fanatical are both owned by Fandom

item.title: Someone Ported Doom To Run Inside A PDF
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/someone-ported-doom-to-run-inside-a-pdf/1100-6528790/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Emails are about to be way more interesting. A developer has created a Doom port that can be played within a PDF file on a web browser. Aptly named "doom.pdf," the file allows you to boot up the original game and control the character using your keyboard, following the usual WASD movement scheme, the space bar to shoot, and the numbers one to seven to circle between weapons.

The developer, who goes by ading.dev, shared some details about the process behind the hilarious project via Bluesky. It's a bit on the technical side of things, but the port was possible thanks to PDFs supporting JavaScript. Using Emscripten, a compiler that compiles C and C++ source code to WebAssembly, they compiled Doom to asm.js, a subset of JavaScript. In short, it's how ading.dev got Doom running in a PDF.

Both input and output are done by manipulating text input fields. If you aren't tech-savvy, don't worry, as you don't need to manually input commands. In order to play the game, all you need is to open doom.pdf and follow the instructions. You can either click on the control layout on screen, or type inside a box to mimick the keyboard controls. If the game doesn't work, make sure that you're opening the PDF in Chromium-based browsers (such as Google Chrome.)

While doom.pdf is far from the best way to play Id Software's classic shooter, it's a marvel to see the port in action. It's yet the latest example of developers and programming enthusiasts capitalizing on dozens of absurd iterations over the years, including potato-sourced electricity powering a calculator. If you're wondering what the current state of Doom is as a franchise, Doom: The Dark Ages is set to arrive in 2025. In June 2024, developers at Id Software said that Doom 1 and Doom 2 were inspirations for the protagonist's origins in the upcoming entry. If you're curious to learn more about it, Doom: The Dark Ages has a spot in the upcoming Xbox Developer Direct later this month.

Diego Nicolás Argüello on Google+

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: First Look At The Blood Of Dawnwalker Reveals A Medieval World Ruled By Vampires
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/first-look-at-the-blood-of-dawnwalker-reveals-a-medieval-world-ruled-by-vampires/1100-6528789/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

In February 2022, The Witcher 3 director Konrad Tomaszkiewicz founded Rebel Wolves alongside some other veteran developers. The first tease for the studio's inaugural game, The Blood of Dawnwalker, arrived last month. But now, Rebel Wolves has debuted the opening moments of the game, which establish how a valley in medieval Europe fell under control of vampires.

The trailer introduces the game's main character, Coen, as he attempts to save his plague-stricken sister, Lunka, from the human authorities who intend to execute her. Their lives are spared by the arrival of Brencis and his vampires, who quickly dispatch the guards. Brencis then heals Lunka and tells Coen that they are seizing control of the valley.

That scene takes place before the beginning of the game. When the main story begins, Coen and his fellow villagers have been living under the vampire regime for two years. Coen is also the titular Dawnwalker, because his silver poisoning prevented him from turning into a full vampire. Instead, Coen remains human during the day, and he transforms into a powerful vampire at night.

Although the developers stressed the narrative freedom that The Blood of Dawnwalker will give players, there is a ticking clock. Coen only has 30 days and 30 nights to save his family from Brencis' dungeons, and time is a commodity that he has to choose how to spend. Players can also decide to make allies with those who share his desire to bring down the vampires, but not everyone's agenda will line up with Coen's.

The developers also noted that the vampires do have human supporters, because Brencis has kept them safe and healed them from the plague. But the vampires also treat the humans like cattle, and they aren't free to leave the valley. They've just traded their human feudal lords for vampires who took their place.

The Blood of Dawnwalker doesn't currently have a release date, but the gameplay reveal will arrive this summer.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Hyper Light Breaker Finally Launches Into Early Access This Week, New Trailer Showcases What To Expect
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/hyper-light-breaker-finally-launches-into-early-access-this-week-new-trailer-showcases-what-to-expect/1100-6528788/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Hyper Light Breaker drops into early access on PC on January 14 (tomorrow!) and now it's got a trailer to match. The game is a 3D, open-world, co-op, rogue-lite sequel to Hyper Light Drifter.

Up to three players can explore the randomly generated worlds of Hyper Light Breaker. In that world they'll find bosses called Crowns, and, of course, plenty of weapons and loot to augment each player's build. This new entry is a departure from the series' past. Hyper Light Drifter was a single-player, pixelated, isometric action game. However, both share a neon-drenched color scheme, an emphasis on fast-paced action, and a story communicated mostly through gesture and aesthetic.

The trailer shows most of this off. It follows a party of three "Breakers," who all have their own unique builds, as they explore the world. One wields a blue laser swords with a rifle. Another has a giant hammer. Special abilities also play a role, as one character drops a giant cube onto an enemy. The trio share movement abilities, including wall runs, hang-gliders, and hoverboards. The trailer also features footage from multiple boss battles, including one with a giant sword-wielding wolf and another against a glowing, armored warrior in a coliseum. Hyper Light Breaker was originally set to release in early access in Spring 2023. It got delayed to Fall 2023 and then further delayed into early 2025. You can wishlist it on Steam now.

In GameSpot's Hyper Light Breaker preview, Jordan Ramée wrote, "I feel like my big takeaway from my time with Hyper Light Breaker is that I need to give it another chance. This first impression wasn't very good... But games launch in early access for this very reason, and it's possible that most of my concerns won't be in the game when I play it again." In between Hyper Light games, developer Heart Machine released action platformer Solar Ash.

Grace Benfell on Google+

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: You Can Sign Up For The Skate Beta On Consoles Now
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/you-can-sign-up-for-the-skate-beta-on-consoles-now/1100-6528787/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Skate is aiming to arrive in early access this year, and there's a new beta to sign up for. If you want to throw your name in the hat for the chance to playtest the game on consoles ahead of release, publisher EA has opened up registrations to do so.

Announced via X (formerly known as Twitter), those interested can sign in via the Skate Insider Playtesting program. Fancy name aside, EA hopes to receive feedback from selected players. As stated on the site, the studio is inviting people to playtest on Xbox and PlayStation. This comes after an initial playtest on PC last year.

While there's no guarantee on how soon people will get to try the beta, EA says it's begun to increase the number of players invited. Insiders will also receive an in-game skateboard and stickers as rewards when the game launches in early access.

skate. Insider Playtest Gameplay Highlights: September 2024

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

EA also took the chance to address some community questions in the announcement video. Mainly, that console playtesting was originally slated for Fall 2024, and now "it's here," and that there'll be more Black hairstyle customization options available in the final game.

Skate is a revival of the beloved skateboarding series, which has otherwise been dormant since Skate 3 released in 2010. It's being developed by Vancouver-based studio Full Circle. The staff includes Deran Chung and Cuz Parry, who previously worked on the three mainline games.

Sadly, there are no more substantial details about Skate for the time being. Those who are taking part in playtests can't share information about the game. But in case you missed it, developer Full Circle shared details about the revamped Flick-It system and plans for an ever-changing city back in June last year.

Diego Nicolás Argüello on Google+

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
